body:
I don't have a strong preference, except to choose one and have it running right away. Both are free for open source, both are trivial to set up. We can change at any time. We can even use both to see which makes us happier.

It does look like there is also a [coveralls browser extension](https://github.com/kwonoj/coveralls-overlay), though unsupported. Getting coverage data into the pull request is a must-have for it to be useful to me.

As I noted in the PR description, we already execute random scripts. Any user can add their own script to `.travis.yml` and it will be executed.
I'm not sure between `integration/java` and `sdks/java/integration`. I think I prefer the second one a bit more. Even more, we might want to do `sdks/java/integration/nexmark`.

Copying from a previous PR: I'd prefer `sdks/java/io` as opposed to top-level `io`, given that all IOs are SDK-specific. Also, I'd say all GCP IO should probably go in the same module, as opposed to a module per-product.

R: @kennknowles @davorbonaci 

is it possible to kick the Jenkins now that it's been fixed? Otherwise, what's blocking merge?
LGTM.
pong
Random attempt:
Jenkins, retest this please.
LGTM
R: @davorbonaci
LGTM. Merged, no backport.
Merged in apache/master to force re-run of tests
Merged; no backport.
rebased and repushed to trigger jenkins rerun

R: @davorbonaci
(I'd also like to take a peek.)

@peihe Incorporated your suggestion. For a large number of accumulators, this happens to be worse due to the indexing, but I suppose a small number of accumulators is more common. The difference is in the nanosecond-per-element range either way...

Unfortunately, we don't know how to kick Jenkins to re-run the build without pushing to this branch. If somebody has an idea, I'd love to hear it. (Standard things like Rebuild button in Jenkins UI and adding the specific comment here don't work.)

I think this is merge-ready. I'd leave it to @mxm -- just in case if there's any comment on Kenn's previous one, or if @mshields822 wants to add anything.
The build integration part is not about security. If it is integrated into the Maven build lifecycle, it is one-step does it all, as opposed to having to execute two separate steps.

I don't think we should take the build seriously until the pubsub pull
request is in since this builds on top. I've put it here so I can point to
it this fri and get the early stuff done.

Not really fussed about the directory name, whatever seems best is fine.
But it will depend on at least one runner so putting under sdks/... seems
misleading. Thought about examples/... but the code quality there is
significantly higher :-)

wrote:

Looking at the ci failure the grpc-pubsub.jar (containing all the pubsub proto-derived classes) is jdk8 only. Advice?

R: @davorbonaci 
for help with ci failure above

The two pubsub/grpc jars this depends on have been compiled with jdk8 and thus break our jdk7 support requirement. I'm taking this up with the Google team responsible. We can review this but we can't merge until that is sorted out.
Use an OffsetBasedSource for the whole thing.

One way to kick Jenkins, which seems fine at this point, would be to rebase to a different upstream commit (it doesn't really matter which one).

Agree that it should just be merged. We have a very strong signal from Travis, and in fact the Flink runner tests run first in Jenkins so they are known to have passed.
This is actually a feature. A failure of the coverage upload does not fail the build. We can and should configure Jenkins the same way.
Sorry this has been sitting - I am bringing myself up to speed. Just letting you know it is not forgotten.
Just a couple nits & questions, then LGTM.
This is a very large PR. I am going to need to take another pass to continue to grok.
One thing you could do that would lighten the cognitive load would be to separate the source and sink into two PRs.
It's an LGTM party!
Not a feature; and completely orthogonal point. Plugins can be configured not to fail the build on errors. In this case, the configuration property is called `failOnServiceError`.
R: @bjchambers
Thanks for the comments. I can kick the Jenkins build (as a Jenkins job admin). Just did that and will merge after tests have passed.
LGTM (with late sorry)

@amitsela any comment on expanding GBK in the spark runner? It should leave the behavior exactly as it was before. This is the intended method of runner-specific replacements until the new pipeline transformation API is ready.

+1 to Mark's last point. When modules are all split, we are going to want this dependency direction:

integration tests → runner(s) → SDK

Otherwise we have a cycle between runners and SDK. Is there another option?

LGTM
Waiting on tests to finish running.

It seems codecov is not compatible with Apache policies, so I am closing this and will proceed with coveralls.

This looks nice to me. Some magic, but reduces the amount of code.

Let's leave this pull request open for a week or so. This will give more people a chance to comment on this code pattern.

R=@bjchambers 
In case you want to cherry pick this and Repeatably trigger bug fixes.

Also note: AutoValue is a build-time dependency only. The `@AutoValue` annotation is marked with `@RetentionPolicy.SOURCE`, meaning the annotations discarded after compilation. The annotation processor generates package-private classes that should only be used within the implementation of the abstract class. In the pom.xml, the dependency is marked `<scope>provided</scope>`, meaning the dependency isn't transitive and won't be present at runtime.

PTAL (really need to squash history now)
- Avoid SimpleFunction, move the bucking/moving functions stuff into util
- Split off GrpcClient  iface as you suggest.

So now we could proceed as
 GrpcClient and friends
 PubsubUnboundedSink
 PubsubUnboundedSource and friends

R: @bjchambers

This looks good to me. Let's wait to see if Kenn sees anything since he has fresh eyes (may identify other places for improvement).

One question -- do we have a test that takes all the kinds of display data and writes them to JSON and looks at the details of that encoding (eg., whether a number is written as a number or a string, etc.)? This would be valuable, since changes to the JSON format will have the potential to break runners/UIs that depend on the display data coming across in a specific format.
Jenkins, retest this please.

LGTM

Will give @kennknowles a chance to comment and then merge. Kenn -- let me know if you'd prefer I go ahead and merge now.

@dhalperi for discussion. If `XmlCoder` is not suitable for intermediate usage, should we really have `XmlSource` set that as the coder for its output?
LGTM, will merge pending discussion.

R: @dhalperi so the scripts pick it up.
Please put `[BEAM-22]` in the PR/commit description?

My main comment is that we should probably fix JAXBCoder to behave correctly in inner context. That is backwards-incompatible, but it fixes a bug that is probably causing crashes if users are using it this way.
R: @davorbonaci to comment on backwards-incompatible change.
